text: Or i wonder if theyll leave lightning bolt alone and it cant hit planeswalkers anymore? Haha
That would be terrible
I think any targeted damage spell will be able to hit walkers, but I don't know about general damage effects like Pyrohemia
If they errata it would have to be or in general damage, else it makes them so much better.
Right, that's my thought.
But if they errata them your way they'll be so much better.
Pyrohemia now says it deals 1 to each player, planeswalker and creature.
It does upgrade them, but then again that's sorta how the spell was supposed to function, they just didn't know it yet
And yes there were some designed since planeswalkers that were intended to make you choose, but that'll be so messy if there's a split
Hmm
They must have it worked out internally. It'll be interesting to see what they say
I think it should be player or Planeswalker across the board on those.
(For the record, when you asked me why would errata be messier, this is exactly what I was talking about)
This isn’t really what I would call messy, just a point of clarification.

Honestly if they’re consistent and use the wording player or Planeswalker there’s no need for clarification. There’s no reason to believe they would use ‘and’ unless it already expressly said so, such as Hour of Devastation.

but like, with pyrohemia example, if they do or, the selection isn't per person, it's for the whole activation, and if you do that you actually do get more than before right? cause now it'll hit all the walkers as opposed to only hitting one per activation
will be interesting

Messiness requires points of clarification. 

Or, going forward, what if they want to print a card that actually can only hit players or creatures, and not planeswalkers? Despite having the same text as lightning Bolt and Lightning Strike, it will be a completely different card. What if they'd like to make a new lava spike? They're complicating their own ability to make certain types of cards going forward. 
It's a good change, the redirection rule sucks. Invisible text just kinda sucks too. Good rules changes answer more questions than they raise

It’s an unrealistic expectation that any rules change wouldn’t require points of clarification for a game of the complexity and age of MTG. Every rule change requires clarification and therefore is messy by your definition. There’s no way around it.

We grokked the legendary planeswalkers pretty easy. Damage no longer using the stack too. Lack of mana burn went down without a hitch. Even commander rules changes were clean; you can make any colored mana now, and tuck is gone. Players had ire about them, but not because they were complicated. 

In like two years this won't be an issue, but until then, it makes things weird for a new player. They'll have to re-examine every red card they see. Any rule change requires clarification, I'm not stupid. I'm saying they require minor clarification compared to this. This requires card-by-card re-evaluation, and that's a barrier to entry. It'll solve itself in time, but for the moment, it's a lot less clean than changing tuck or legendary planeswalkers
I think edh is the worst off
Standard is fine bc all cards will be printed correctly. Legacy and modern see much smaller set of cards played
Edh we play all sorts of stupid jank
Pyrohemia/pestilence, bolts, things like [[drain life]]

text: I just hope they come up with some sort of easy to remember rule of thimb

<@U3MTJRAQL> I didn’t mean to imply you were stupid. @Don, each of those instances are variations of the same situation. I suspect they will word it to keep the same effect today, but instead of calling it redirect, the spell’s controller chooses to hit either the player or a planeswalker that player controls. I doubt they would go with allowing hitting each Planeswalker a player controls as that seriously amps up the power of those spells.

My son got a hard lesson in varying definitions of fun yesterday playing edh @ madness (3rd biggest card store in America atm).

We podded up with an alpha that had 5 decks each running $3k worth of seriously optimized power that like to lock and win on turns 3-4 on average. It was savage and we got to have the father son competitive magic talk.

I don't care for podstompers
How old is your son again?
Been playing since he was 14.
Well, that's old enough to be able to handle dealing with jerkfaces
Oh yeah, he was having an existential crisis.
You're not Dante's Dad, are you?
Why play this format if it's just singleton vintage and whatnot.
He wasn't even supposed to be there yesterday.:joy:

I had to remind him of the freedom of choice in edh. That guy is now a known alpha, when you see him in the water you can choose not to swim around him. Aka don't pod with him. Politely decline and go play with others.
Are you the commanderruminations guy?

I'm open about my ocd but not exactly wanting to be defined by it.

If yes, I was following your blog for awhile

I'd love to see more people do shop reviews like that.

I talked about having ocd and ruminating alot

Oh ok I thought that was a clerks reference

text: Seems super silly for RG Omnath as well.
I have an RG omnath, I don't think I'd run this
Why not?
Or rather, what do you run for card draw?

Elemental bond, kavu lair, shamanic revelation, rishkar's expertise, tireless tracker. On the expensive end, sylvan library and greater good. I think I'd run harmonize and collective unconscious over the Overwhelming Instinct. It just seems fragile
If we aren't persistently aggressing with 3+ tokens a turn then what are we doing besides going for war storm surge triggers?
All of those seem fine btw, preferentially I prefer persistent draw vs. one shot draw although both have situations where they are the better option.
There are, for sure. I'm just wary. I think there's a reason [[Military Intelligence]] shows up in less than 500 decks, and it applies even more to the Instinct

text: I disagree respectfully. Military Intelligence is blue, and has an extremely awkward design for the color. Blue is the premier card advantage color and asking it to attack (out of character for the color) and attack in multiples (not really a swarm color traditionally) makes for a card that situationally is far less applicable than overwhelming instinct.
Simply put, the color as better options for the same effect and so the comparison is far from apples to apples.
Best angry omnath decks I’ve seen aren’t too worried about combat, they’re just making elemental with landfall or stuff like firecat blitz and tempt with vengeance and mass saccing
Intellect, however, has competition on color and for cheaper (cmc wise) but financially can be an issue. For the swarm approach I see no reason it can't flourish.
I mean, sure. I just kinda think Green also has better options for that effect
Edh wise I wouldn’t say blue is best for draw. I’d pick black and you could argue green
Argue green over blue I mean
Really? Consecrated sphinx and rhystic study would like to have a word with you.
Ambitions cost/ancient craving > con sphinx
I will just agree to disagree with you.
Study and brainstorm are great though
There is no way I will ever take one shot draw over persistence.
Sphinx gets better the worse your opponents I guess
Not in that context at least.
But again, that's just my opinion.
I think if your meta allows for black to feel better than blue for advantage due to relaxed levels of interaction then take advantage of it.
I’ll take one shot draw over stuff that requires your ipponents to not respond unless it’s really cheap like rhystic study or arena or remora
It’s the opposite; black is better than blue when your meta runs removal, ie interactiin
You are all nerds and should feel bad
Blue (sphinx) is better when people just watch you and play
I personally don’t like to rely on my opponents not doing stuff to have things work
I love cantrips.
I run ponder, preordain and brainstorm every chance I get.
Brainstorm is way underplayed
